body:
Hi @noopur2507,

You're not missing anything: the architecture was never designed to support registration of  a `TestExecutionListener` per `LauncherDiscoveryRequest`.

Rather, a `TestExecutionListener` is registered for a specific `Launcher` instance.

Is it a problem for you to create multiple `Launcher` instances? If so, then the architecture will have to be changed to support such use cases; however, that will likely introduce breaking changes in the current API.

@junit-team/junit-lambda, anyone else have further input on this?
@noopur2507, while we have your attention, would you mind commenting on https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/504#issuecomment-269302164? ðŸ˜‰

> Is it a problem for you to create multiple Launcher instances?

No, creating separate `Launcher` instances is not a problem and solves the issue. But for a single launch having multiple requests, it results in an unnecessary overhead of discovering/loading the test engines with each instance of `Launcher`.

> @noopur2507, while we have your attention, would you mind commenting on #504 (comment)?

Done.

> But for a single launch having multiple requests, it results in an unnecessary overhead of discovering/loading the test engines with each instance of `Launcher`.

Yes, that's true. But... out of curiosity, how long does that take on your machine? 

I would imagine that's actually a pretty fast process, though I admittedly have not benchmarked it.

It is fast i.e. takes around 40 ms for `LauncherFactory.create()` call for the first time. For further invocations in the same run, it reduces to 2-4 ms. So looks like some internal caching/optimization is available.

Another issue with multiple `Launcher` instances could be related to memory consumption.

It can be used as the solution for now but would not be the preferred way to handle it.

> @noopur2507 Thanks for checking!

ðŸ‘ 

> We could add an overloaded `execute(LauncherDiscoveryRequest, TestExecutionListener)` method that uses the supplied `TestExecutionListener` in addition to already registered listeners but only for the supplied `LauncherDiscoveryRequest`.

Yes. That seems plausible.
